Award.AwardTitle: Topological Recursion and Its Influence in Analysis, Geometry, and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial participant support for the 2016 von Neumann Symposium, "Topological Recursion and Its Influence in Analysis, Geometry, and Topology," held July 4-8, 2016 in Charlotte, North Carolina, coordinated by the American Mathematical Society. Topological recursion is an emerging field of mathematics discovered independently in the study of random matrices and in studies of dynamics and geometry. The novelty of topological recursion is its universal applicability to many problems arising in areas of mathematics and quantum physics. For example, Catalan numbers, simple combinatorial expressions that occur in various counting problems, have generalizations associated with surfaces of complicated structure that can be calculated effectively by topological recursion. The exact same formula computes important quantities arising in the study of quantum gravity. Topological recursion not only provides theoretical formulas for many concrete problems in mathematics and physics, but also furnishes a practical computational tool. The interplay between machine computation and mathematical proof has been a driving force for recent rapid development of the field, in which many outstanding conjectures have been resolved, while new mysteries have arisen, both on the theoretical front and in computer experiments. This timely symposium, in which half of the invited speakers are early-career researchers, is aimed to further advance this exciting, rapidly-developing field.

Topological recursion is a new emerging field of mathematics developed in statistical mechanical study of random matrices. Independently, essentially the same structure of the theory was discovered in research on the volume of moduli spaces of bordered hyperbolic surfaces. Due to the simple nature of concrete recursive formulas, topological recursion relates many current research frontiers of mathematics in a novel and understandable way. For example, counting Hurwitz numbers, Gromov-Witten theory, Gaiotto's conjecture on opers arising from string theory, the WKB analysis of Schroedinger equations, and the relation between A-polynomials and colored Jones polynomials for knots and their generalizations are all deeply related through ideas stemming from topological recursion. The goal of the symposium is to promote interest among young researchers in this exciting research frontier and to significantly enhance the subject matter by disseminating recent progress and identifying important problems for future development. POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funding was awarded to support the 2016 American Mathematical Society von Neumann Symposium. This prestigious conference is held only once in 5 to 6 years, and competitive selection of the topics is determined by a committee. The 2016 symposium was held in Charlotte, North Carolina, from July 4 to July 8, under the title, Topological Recursion and its Influence in Analysis, Geometry, and Topology.

A total of 50 mathematicians participated in the conference, of whom 20 were from the US institutions. This truly international conference was represented by the following countries: Australia, Canada, China, Denmark, France, Germany, Japan, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Russia, South Korea, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and the United States.

A total of 26 graduate students and recent PhDs received the NSF support toward their travel to the conference. These recipients include two mini-course speakers, 4 plenary session speakers, and 6 contributed section speakers.

One of the mini-courses and a contributed talk were devoted to the recent solution of a significant conjecture of the field, the re-modeling conjecture made by theoretical physicists working in the area of topological string theory, in 2008. This conjecture states that topological recursion can be used to give a precise description of the B-model topological string theory. This conjecture, which leads to a concrete and new mathematical theorem in Gromov-Witten theory, was soved in 2016, and two of the solvers gave talks at the conference.

Another significant conjecture of 2014, again made my a prominent physicist in the area of algebraic geometry of Hitchin systems, was solved in 2016, and one of the solvers gave a plenary talk at the conference. This conjecture relates quantization of an algebraic curve and a construction of an oper, a globally defined system of differential equations on the algebraic curve. The relation between this quantization and topological recursion was also a recent achievement of the area of research.

In addition to solutions to important conjectures, a totally new way of understanding topological recursion was also presented at the conference. This result has already influenced the research community, and many new papers from this new point of view have been produced.

The conference played a pivotal role in enhancing the visibility of topological recursion in the UC research community. It also triggered productivity of young participants in the field. The number of papers carrying the word "topological recursion" in the title or the abstract that are posted in arXiv in the year right after the conference has seen a 100% increase, compared to papers posted the one year period prior to the conference. Many of the authors of these new papers are young scholars who participated in the conference, indicating the impact of the conference.

The NSF award functioned effectively in bringing top scholars in this emerging new field of research to the US. At the same time, the funding allowed recent PhDs and graduate students to learn the new materials and to start new collaborations. The increased productivity of the research community is a good indication of the impact of the award and the conference.
